This is an incomplete list of some literature that members of MITNB added. Some of the papers tackle multiple of the topics listed.

## Theoretical papers/reviews

**Schwarz, N., & Strack, F. (1999).** [Reports of Subjective Well-Being: Judgmental Processes and Their Methodological Implications.](https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2021.764526) In D. Kahneman, E. Diener, & N. Schwarz (Eds.), Well-being: The Foundations of Hedonic Psychology (pp. 61--84). Russell Sage Foundation. 
<!-- - Describes different theories regarding response processes in making judgments about subjective well-being. -->

**Norman, G. (2003).** [Hi! How Are You? Response Shift, Implicit Theories and Differing Epistemologies.](https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1023211129926) Quality of Life Research, 12(3), 239--249. 
<!-- - Discusses response shifts in quality of life research. -->

**Ram, N., Brinberg, M., Pincus, A. L., & Conroy, D. E. (2017).** [The Questionable Ecological Validity of Ecological Momentary Assessment: Considerations for Design and Analysis.](https://doi.org/10.1080/15427609.2017.1340052) Research in Human Development, 14(3), 253--270. 
<!-- - Outlines several problems related to validity in EMA research (e.g., measurement reactivity, lack of compliance, choice of response scales). -->

**Kuppens, P., Dejonckheere, E., Kalokerinos, E. K., & Koval, P. (2022).** [Some Recommendations on the Use of Daily Life Methods in Affective Science.](https://doi.org/10.1007/s42761-022-00101-0) Affective Science, 3(2), 505--515. 
<!-- - General recommendations about EMA studies, but also has a part about measurement (and how heavily it's understudied). -->

**Leertouwer, Ij., Cramer, A. O. J., Vermunt, J. K., & Schuurman, N. K. (2021).** [A Review of Explicit and Implicit Assumptions When Providing Personalized Feedback Based on Self-Report EMA Data.](https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2021.764526) Frontiers in Psychology, 12, 764526. 
<!-- - Describes assumptions related to the impact of personal feedback. Particularly relevant also for studies regarding response processes! -->

**Zumbo, B. D., & Hubley, A. M. (Eds.). (2017).** [Understanding and Investigating Response Processes in Validation Research.](https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-56129-5) Springer International Publishing. 
<!-- - Not specific to EMA, but gives information about cognitive interviewing! -->

## Validity

**Cloos, L. J. R., Kuppens, P., & Ceulemans, E. (in press).** [Development, validation, and comparison of self-report measures for positive and negative affect in intensive longitudinal research.](https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/5j7c6) In Psychological Assessment.

## Reliability

**Dejonckheere, E., Demeyer, F., Geusens, B., Piot, M., Tuerlinckx, F., Verdonck, S., & Mestdagh, M. (2022).** [Assessing the Reliability of Single-Item Momentary Affective Measurements in Experience Sampling.](https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0001178) Psychological Assessment.

## Measurement reactivity/Initial elevation bias

(2022).** [A Mixed-Method Investigation into Measurement Reactivity to the Experience Sampling Method: The Role of Sampling Protocol and Individual Characteristics.](https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0001177) Psychological Assessment. Advance online publication.

**König, L. M., Allmeta, A., Christlein, N., Van Emmenis, M., & Sutton, S. (2022).** [A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Studies of Reactivity to Digital In-the-Moment Measurement of Health Behaviour.](https://doi.org/10.1080/17437199.2022.2047096) Health Psychology Review, 1--25.

**Reynolds, B. M., Robles, T. F., & Repetti, R. L. (2016).** [Measurement Reactivity and Fatigue Effects in Daily Diary Research with Families.](https://doi.org/10.1037/dev0000081) Developmental Psychology, 52(3), 442--456.

**Cerino, E., Schneider, S., Stone, A., Sliwinski, M., Mogle, J., & Smyth, J. (2022).** [Little Evidence for Consistent Initial Elevation Bias in Self-Reported Momentary Affect: A Coordinated Analysis of Ecological Momentary Assessment Studies.](https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0001108) Psychological Assessment, 34.
